text: over the last 20 years approximately 500
so-called recreational water trails have
been established in the United States
taking kayakers and canoeists down
rivers along coastlines and into
swamplands water trails have become a
way of bringing people to places they
may not normally go allowing them to see
natural areas from a different
perspective or vantage point as outdoor
adventure mecca's go Alabama a state
without a single national park in it has
long been considered parts unknown to
the adventure travel set a blank spot on
the map when it comes to the National
Geography of pulse quickening
nature-based experiences and yet outdoor
enthusiasts to live here will tell you
that this is not because album is
lacking in natural beauty local
advocates contend the state's cypress
line whitewater stretches Moss drape
Appalachian cliff faces and deep woods
simply remain Western own but there is
hope that a newly established path over
water set to be unveiled in early June
will change that we're working to launch
the Alabama Scenic River Trail that's
going to be 631 miles the longest river
trail in the single state the new
Alabama Scenic River Trail which is
comprised of seven rivers and two creeks
starts in the coastal river at the
Alabama Georgia state line near the
small town of Osceola in the
northeastern part of the state it ends
at Fort Morgan State Historic Site in
Mobile Bay after running through the
second largest river delta in the
country
the trail was originally envisioned by
67 year old Alabama and Fred couch a
jeweler paddler and community activists
who felt that Alabama needed a boost the
project now has 50 to 80 volunteers and
scores of public and private interest
involved among the key volunteers in
this effort is 70 year old native
Thornton Corp we've taken teams down the
river recently several times checking
out the mileages the facilities the
places where once you get down into the
Delta you need to identify where you
want to make a turn draw a line from one
spot to the next over water market and
the idea is that people will come
according to Jeff Duncan rivers program
manager for the Southeast region of the
National Park Service's rivers trails
and conservation assistance program
there's been a vast increase in the
number of water trail the local
communities want to create that's
definitely a movement it's a foot yeah
nobody ever came to me and said hey you
know wake up it's time to do this it's
like everybody I talked to during the
day I mean my business associates my
camping buddies my kayaking buddies
hiking cycling buddies everybody says
you know this is happening you know we
better help it out the Alabama Scenic
River Trail joins the relatively small
class of less than 20 long distance
water trails there are approximately 100
miles or more in the United States
however unlike many other inland water
trails that are typically nature based
or found along narrow water passages the
Alabama Scenic River Trail is far more
Mississippi lake in character and dotted
with the litany of natural and historic
attractions long stretches the great
wide river await the paddler locks the
dams bridges and the occasional big ship
or part of the trip
sites accessible from the water include
the cahaba the crumbled ruins of
Alabama's original state capital
clearly the most interesting historical
site is the edmund pettus bridge from
the selma to montgomery march and most
people go over it in a car or on foot
and don't realize what a beautiful
graceful arch it is and the only way to
see that is from down in the river
on a secluded stretch of Alabama some 50
miles downstream from Selma paddlers can
physically see the southernmost point of
the Appalachian Mountains along the
banks of the river in the Delta section
near mobile floating wooden platforms
can be used as campsites and alligators
are added to the list of wildlife
attraction was visible while paddling it
took organizers of the 740 mile northern
forest new trail over 10 years to open
its water trail the Alabama Scenic River
Trail have gone from idea to reality in
less than two years though not without
room for continued improvement
significant toil from volunteers and
fundraising challenge
some cases however these waterways need
a little or no additional amenity to
prepare them for an influx of outdoor
enthusiasts simply drop a boat in the
water and let the river do the rest this
is Christopher Percy Collier for the New
